tr.td: KinOath is a kinship application with the primary goal of connecting kinship data with archived data, such as audio, video or written resources while also being closely integrated with the archive software such as Arbil. Beyond this primary goal it is designed to be flexible and culturally nonspecific, such that culturally different social structures can equally be represented. Kin type strings are used throughout the application for constructing and searching data sets. The representation of kin terms is also integrated into the application allowing comparative diagrams of kin terms. Graphical representation of the data is an important part of the application and the diagrams produced are intended to very flexible and of publishable quality.

chapter.title: Navigating KinOath
chapter.para: KinOath is part of the Language Archiving Technology suite. You will find a link to the program on the LAT web page http://www.lat-mpi.eu/tools/kinoath/ . KinOath is an online tool, it does not need to be installed, but you will need Java installed on your machine for it to run. For more information on Java and how to install it http://java.com/en/.

chapter.title: Menus
chapter.para: Once KinOath has been opened, the various diagrams and their relative options can be accessed through a number of menus collocated at the top of the page.

section.title: File menu
section.para: The first one is the File menu, which includes the following options:

listitem.para: New (default diagram): this option allows you to open a new diagram. It says 'default' because the type of diagram which is opened is the same as the one which was previously set as default diagram (see option 'Set Default Diagram as' below).
New Diagram of Type: this option allows you to open a new diagram choosing among the different types given (see section 2.1.1.)
Open: this option allows you to open a new diagram file from a directory in your computer.

Open Recent Diagram: through this option you can select and re-open one of the diagrams which were previously opened. If you want to delete the list you can select Clear list (at the end of the list).
Open Sample Diagram: KinOath includes a number of sample diagrams through which you can observe how the program works. You can see them by selecting this option. (See section 2.1.2.)
Import Gedcom / CSV File: this option allows you to import in KinOath files in either Gedcom or CSV format.
Import Sample Data: the Query Diagram requires data to be imported. A list of sample data is accessible via this option.
Entity Upload: this option is not available at the moment. It will be functioning for the next release of KinOath.
Save as: when selecting this option you will be asked to choose a directory and enter a file name in order to save the file.
Export as PDF: this option allows you to export the file to a directory in PDF format.
Export to R / SPSS: this option allows you to export a KinOath diagram to either R or SPSS, two programs for statistical computing.
Close: clicking on this option will close the program.

Set Default Diagram as: through this option you can choose a particular type of diagram and set it as the default diagram, so that when you open KinOath again, this will show you the specific diagram type you chose.
Exit: as with 'Close', clicking on this option will close the program.

section.title: Diagram Types
section.para: Through the option 'New Diagram of Type' a number of different diagrams can be opened:

listitem.para:
Standard Diagram (database driven): when selecting this type, a new page of KinOath will open, with a main, blank panel and a smaller panel on the left called Diagram Tree. You can create a new diagram from scratch using the several options of the menu that comes out when right clicking in the main panel:
Add: you may decide to add an Individual or a Chromosome_Example to your diagram. In both cases, a new entity will appear under the form of a small square, representing an unspecified ego. If you select that entity you will see, at the bottom of the page, a table with information to fill in: 'Name', 'Date of Birth', 'Date of Death', 'Gender' (in the case of the chromosome example you will also see the voice 'Chromosome'). Once the data regarding an ego have been entered you can save them either by clicking on the ego itself, or by choosing - from the right click menu - the option Save All Data Changes.
Add Geometry: its sub-options are: Add Label, Add Circle, Add Square, Add Polyline, and Add Ellipse. The first (label) allows you to enter a label for your diagram, and you can do it by entering the text into a small window opening at the bottom of the page when the option is selected. The other four are graphic options you can use to create different kin groups (circle, square, ellipse) or to link the entities with more than one single line (polyline).
Delete: this option allows you to delete the entity/ies you created from the diagram but also from the database.
Merge Selected Entities: you can use this option when, for example, you have two separate entities including different data but you discover that they are the same individual, and therefore you want to make them merge into a single one.
Duplicate Selected Entities: when choosing this option, the entity/ies previously selected will be doubled.
Add Relations: once several, single entities have been created you may want to create relations between them. To this purpose, select how many entities you need (by clicking on them while holding down the SHIFT button on the keyboard) and right click. You can choose between: sibling, ancestor, descendant, union, kinterm, other. In addition, if you want to add only a 'descendant' or 'ancestor' relation, you can simply select one entity and drag the blue line to the other.
Remove Relations: you may also want to change some of the relations created. To do so, select the necessary entities, right click, and choose 'Remove Relations' - Remove relations between selected.
Set as ego (replacing list): in the diagram tree panel on the left you see three lists, Ego, Required, and Implied. When you create new entities they automatically go under the 'Required' list or, depending on the relations that have been created, under the 'Implied' list. However, if you want to create an egocentric diagram you can select one of the entities and - through 'Set as ego' - transfer it to the 'Ego' list. This will highlighted in black. You can also create socialcentric diagrams, in which no particular ego is highlighted.
Add to ego list: this option is similar to the previous one. You can select entities and add them to the 'Ego' list on the left.
Remove from ego list: through this option you can move entities from the 'Ego' list back to the 'Required' list.
Keep on diagram: with this option you decide to keep the selected entity/ies onto the digram.
Release from the diagram: with this option you remove the selected entity/ies from the diagram, but in this case it/they remain(s) in the database, unlike with the option 'Delete'.
Reset Zoom: when selecting this option the layout of the diagram returns back to its default size.
Reset Layout: it can happen, when you select many entities at a time (see 'Archive Data Linker' diagram below) that they overlap in the diagram so you cannot see them clearly. By resetting the layout such entities are distanced from each other.
Search Entity Service: chiedi a Peter di rispiegartelo
Save All Data Changes: see point 1. above.

Freeform diagram (transient): when selecting this type, a new page of KinOath will open, with a main, blank panel and a smaller panel on the top called Kin Type Strings. Also here you can create diagrams from scratch but the difference with the previous case is that you need to enter strings in the panel on the top of the page, using precise kin types definitions. Hereinafter there is a list of the principal ones (which can be found also via 'Panels' > 'Diagram Settings' > 'Kin Type Definitions'):
E = ego; Ef = ego female; Em = ego male; x = undefied
F or Fa = father; M or Mo = mother; P or Pa = parent
B or Br = brother; Z or Si = sister; Sb = sibling
S or So = son; D or Da = daughter; C or Ch = child
H or Hu = husband; W or Wi = wife; Sp = spouse
* = any relation

Kin Terms Diagram: this type of diagram is useful when you want to observe how social relations are named within a given language and culture (see figure below). When you choose this diagram a new page of KinOath opens, with a main, blank panel, and a smaller panel on the right called Kin Term Group. In the latter, you can see a table that you have to fill in to create your diagram: in the first space (Kin Term) you have to enter the kin terms that represent also the labels of the diagram; in the second (Referent Kin Type Strings) you have to enter, for each kin term, its corresponding definition following the ones listed in the Freeform Diagram; in the fourth (Description) you can add, for example, an English gloss if the kin terms entered are in another language. In addition, you can decide to: a) show the kin terms on the diagram, or to hide them, by checking or unckecking the option Show on graph, above the table; b) delete some of the kin terms entered in the table by checking them and then clicking on Delete Selected, or delete the entire group by simply clicking on Delete Group.

Query Diagram: When you choose this diagram a new page of KinOath opens, with a main, blank panel, the Diagram Tree panel on the left, and the Kin Type Strings panel on the top. This type allows you to search for entities within an already constructed diagram. A list of sample data is accessible through File menu > Import Sample Data. Once you have imported such data you can make a query using basically the definitions listed in the Freeform Diagram, plus other constraints such as names, dates, etc. (see figure below). The entities you have searched for appear both in the tree on the left and in the main panel.

Entity Search: this diagram functions in, more or less, the same way as the query diagram. When you choose it a new page of KinOath opens, with a main, blank panel, the Diagram Tree panel on the left, and another small panel on the right called Search Entities. Here again the search is made on an already existent diagram, and therefore you need to import some data first. Once the data have been imported you make your search by entering a name in the Search space of the right panel. The latter contains an option called Expand selection by kin type string. If you check it and you enter a kin definition, the corresponding entities will appear on the diagram and in the diagram tree in the implied list.

Archive Data Linker: When you choose this diagram a new page of KinOath opens, with a main, blank panel, the Diagram Tree panel on the left, and another panel on the right called Archive Linker. The latter contains the IMDI corpora tree. From a session node of the tree you can take a group of, or the single, actors, and drag them to the main panel. Under each of them you will see the reference to the archive and, at the bottom of the page, a table containing information about them and the corresponding session node of the IMDI tree. You can then link the selected entities by creating relations and/or add, for example, media files, by taking and drag them to the diagram tree on the left under the entity you want them to belong to.

section.title: Sample Diagrams
section.para: Apart from the possibility to work on new diagrams, KinOath includes also a list of sample diagrams which you can observe to get to know the program and its functionalities, and which you can reach through the option 'Open Sample Diagram' from the File menu. These are: Freeform Diagram Syntax, Query Diagram Syntax, Hawaiian Kin Terms, Japanese Kin Terms, Swedish Kin Terms, Named Transient Entities, Matrimonial Ring Examples, Charles II of Spain, and Imported Data Query Example (ANTONIO DE PAULA PESSOA DE /FIGUEIREDO/).

section.title: Edit menu
section.para: This menu contains some options linked to the modification of a diagram:

listitem.para: Select All: by clicking on this option all the entities belonging to the all the diagrams present in the main panel will be highlighted.
Select Related: if you select one entity and then choose this option, all the entities related to the one selected will be hightlighted.
Expand Selection: if you select one entity and then choose this option, only the entities immediately related to the one selected will be highlighted.
Deselect All: this option is for deselecting the entities previously selected.

Recalculate the Diagram: this option allows you to partially modify, or totally recreate, the diagram. Once selected you are allowed to add entities (in the standard diagram), constraints to these (freeform, query, and entity search diagrams), or kin terms and kin groups (kin terms diagram).

section.title: Diagram Options menu
section.para: This menu contains options regarding the layout of the diagram which only have to checked or unchecked acoording to the needs.

listitem.para: Snap To Grid: if checked, this option allows you to move the entity in all directions. If not, you can move the entity just on the sides (see figure below).
Highlight Selected Relations: if checked, when you select one entity, the relations that this has with other, immediately close entities will be highlighted in blue.
Show Diagram Border: if checked, you can see the border of the diagram (a grey line).
Show Sanguin Lines: if unchecked, the lines connecting one entity to the other disappear.
Show Labels: if unchecked, the labels added to the individuals (names for example) when creating the diagram disappear.
Show Kin Type Labels: if unchecked, the kin type definitions next to the to the labels disappear.

Show Id Labels: an Id is added when the same kin type definition is used for different entities, in order to be able to distinguish them; it is represented by a #-sign followed by a number. So for example if you have two male egos, one will be simply Em, and the other Em - #1. If this option is unchecked, you are not able to see Ids.

Show Date Labels: when you create individuals you can also enter a date of birth and of death but, unlike with name and gender, you can decide whether or not to show such dates; if you want them hidden you have to leave this option unchecked.

Show Archive Links: this option is valid only for the diagram type 'Archive Data Linker' where, when you drag entities from the archive into a diagram, you can see also a label of the type: 'archive ref.: 1'. Such label disappears if the option 'Show Archive Links' is unchecked.

section.title: Kin Terms menu
section.para: The whole menu is available only for the Kin Terms Diagram, whereas in the other cases only the option New Kin Term Group can be accessed. This menu includes the following options:

listitem.para: Show: this option allows you to see the kin terms panel on the right. If you uncheck it, the panel disappears and all the other menu options (see below) are not available anymore.

New Kin Term Group: this is the only option from this menu to be available for all the digram types. By selecting it, a new tab will open in the panel on the right in order to add a new group of kin terms. You can choose another colour for this new group by clicking on the bar next to Graph Colour (see figure below). The new kin terms will appear in the diagram next to the previous ones.

Import: instead of creating a new kin terms group from scratch you may decide to import one already existent from a file directory in your computer. To do so, click on the 'Import' option and choose the file you want to import. The kin terms imported will be added to the ones in the table in the right panel and in the diagram also.

Export: with this option you can save (export) the kin terms group created to a directory outside KinOath. By selecting this option a window will open asking you to choose a directory where to place the file, and a file name.
Delete: ???

section.title: Archive Linker menu
section.para: This menu is not fully functional at the moment, but it will be from the next version of KinOath, by which time a better and more detailed explanation will be included in this manual.

section.title: Panels menu
section.para: This menu contains a list of all the panels that can be opened while working on a diagram (some of them have already been mentioned when describing the diagram types). You can choose which ones you want to open simply by checking them.

listitem.para: Archive Linker: by choosing this option a panel will open on the right of the page displaying the IMDI corpora as in the 'Archive Data Linker' diagram.
Diagram Settings: by choosing this option a panel will open on the top of the page with six tabs:

Entity Profiles: this tab includes a list of profiles which can be added or removed when creating a diagram ('Individual' and 'Chromosome_Example' seen in section 2.1.1. in the standard diagram are two examples of profiles). They just need to be checked and unchecked.

Kin Type Definitions: this tab includes a list of the main kin type strings with their corresponding definitions (which have also been reported in this manual in section 2.1.1., freeform diagram). You can delete elements of the list by checking them and then clicking on Delete Delected on the right.
Kin Type Strings: this is the panel the opens up when creating a freeform diagram (see section 2.1.1.), in which you have to enter some strings in order to create individuals, hence diagrams.

Label Fields: this tab contains some information about the entities created by the user (we are referring to the standard diagram type), i.e. name, date of birth, etc. You can delete such pieces of information by clicking on the small squares on the right of the tab. However, they still remain in the table at the bottom of the page (the one filled in when cretaing individuals, so if you want to add them back to the panel on the top you just need to select them (one at a time) and drag them.

Relation Type Definitions: when selecting this tab a sub-table opens. The options of this sub-table displayed here are not mandatory, but if used they may prove useful to simplify the diagram layout. These options are:
Display Name: in this column you can enter the name that you want to give to a particular relation.
Data Category: in this column you can enter an URL which redirects you to a page containing some additional information about the relation types.

Relation Type: as the name says, in this column you can select a type of relation (sibling, union, etc.), choosing among the various possibilities present in the drop down menu. If you do not want to do it manually, you can select Scan For Types under the color table on the right. It will automatically find all the relation types of your diagram and enter them directly in the column Relation Type.
Line Colour: you can choose a different color (from the table on the right) for each of the relation types present in your diagram.
Line Width: ???
Line/Dash: ???
Line Orientation:

Symbol Fields: according to the features that are attributed to the entities, these get different shapes, for example a female ego is a circle, whereas a male ego is a triangle. Such shapes, however, can be modified by choosing among the possibilities included in the drop down lists on the right of the panel. For instance, you may want circles for male egos and triangles for female egos.

Diagram Tree: this panel opens up on the left of the page. It displays three possible lists: Ego, Required, Implied. Let's take the standard diagram type as an example: when you create new individuals, they automatically go under the Required list. If you want an egocentric diagram you have to add an ego, or several egos, depending on how many diagrams you want to create, to the Ego list. The ego/s added to the list go black and represent the reference point of your diagram (see figure below). In addition, ..... manca implied
Export Data: ???
Kin Terms: this panel opens up automatically when working on a Kin Terms Diagram (see section 2.4), since it contains the table with kin terms, kin type strings, descriptions, etc.

Kin Type Strings: this panel opens up automatically in case of a freeform or a query diagram. In it you type the strings necessary to create new individuals (freeform diagram) or to look for them (query diagram).
Search Entities: with this option you can look for determined individuals into an already existent diagram which you have to import first.

section.title: Window menu
section.para: The options of this menu vary according to how many windows of KinOath have been opened. Indeed, it simply consists of a list of the options that have been selected and opened: sample diagrams, new diagrams, etc. Each window has its corresponding menu option checked (see figure below).
